POTASSIUM CHLORIDE

  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Prevention of hypokalaemia (patients with normal diet),

By mouth

  • For adults
    2–4 g daily in divided doses.

Electrolyte imbalance,

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    Dose dependent on deficit or the daily maintenance requirements.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Smaller doses must be used in the prevention of hypokalaemia, to reduce the risk of hyperkalaemia.

Avoid in severe impairment.

Contra indications

  • Plasma-potassium concentration above 5 mmol/litre

Known side effects

Specific side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: abdominal pain, diarrhoea, flatulence, nausea, vomiting,

notKnown: heart toxicity (with rapid infusion), bleeding (with modified-release preparations), gastro-intestinal obstruction (with modified-release preparations), ulceration (with modified-release preparations),

Directions for administration

With intravenous use

Potassium chloride concentrate must be diluted with not less than 50 times its volume of sodium chloride intravenous infusion 0.9% or other suitable diluent and mixed well.

With intravenous use

Ready-mixed infusion solutions should be used where possible; alternatively, potassium chloride concentrate as ampoules containing 1.5 g (K+ 20 mmol) in 10 mL, is thoroughly mixed with 500 mL of sodium chloride 0.9% intravenous infusion and given slowly over 2 to 3 hours with specialist advice and ECG monitoring in difficult cases.

For peripheral intravenous infusion, the concentration of potassium should not usually exceed 40 mmol/L.

Higher concentrations of potassium chloride may be given in very severe depletion, but require specialist advice.

Potassium salts are preferably given as a liquid (or effervescent) preparation, rather than modified-release tablets; they should be given as the chloride (the use of effervescent potassium tablets BPC 1968 should be restricted to hyperchloraemic states).

Modified-release tablets should be swallowed whole with fluid during meals while sitting or standing.

Advice for patients and carers

Salt substitutes

A number of salt substitutes which contain significant amounts of potassium chloride are readily available as health food products (e.g. LoSalt and Ruthmol ). These should not be used by patients with renal failure as potassium intoxication may result.

Patient or carers should be given advice on how to administer potassium chloride modified-release tablets.

Important safety information

Safe practice

Potassium overdose can be fatal. Ready-mixed infusion solutions containing potassium should be used. Exceptionally, if potassium chloride concentrate is used for preparing an infusion, the infusion solution should be thoroughly mixed. Local policies on avoiding inadvertent use of potassium chloride concentrate should be followed.

Cautions regarding administration

  • With intravenous use: seek specialist advice in very severe potassium depletion or difficult cases
  • With oral use: cardiac disease
  • With oral use: elderly
  • With oral use: hiatus hernia (with modified-release preparations
  • With oral use: history of peptic ulcer (with modified-release preparations)
  • With oral use: intestinal stricture (with modified-release preparations)

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Regular monitoring of plasma-potassium concentration is essential in those taking potassium supplements.

With intravenous use

ECG monitoring should be performed in difficult cases.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

With oral use

Potassium Tablets

Do not confuse Effervescent Potassium Tablets BPC 1968 with effervescent potassium chloride tablets. Effervescent Potassium Tablets BPC 1968 do not contain chloride ions and their use should be restricted to hyperchloraemic states.

Conditions when less suitable for prescribing

Modified-release tablets are less suitable for prescribing.

Modified-release preparations should be avoided unless effervescent tablets or liquid preparations inappropriate.

Prepared medicinal forms of POTASSIUM CHLORIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: solution for infusion, oral solution, infusion,
Oral solution
Solution for infusion
Not applicable
